repnme.cdata!:
West Bank and Gaza - First Municipal
            Infrastructure Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for this project are as
            follows: The project outcome is satisfactory, project
            sustainability is likely, the institutional development
            impact is substantial, and the overall performance of the
            World Bank and the Borrower is satisfactory.  Several
            lessons have been learned, of which the most important are
            the following: Commitment at the highest levels of
            government must be very carefully assessed prior to and
            during implementation with projects involving an ambitious
            reform agenda, particularly where issues involving the
            possible devolution of power are involved. Success
            critically depends on strong national (and local) commitment
            and leadership both before and throughout implementation. It
            also depends on the timely provision of competent technical
            assistance. Further, it critically depends on the alignment
            of incentives and accountabilities within the political and
            administrative system, as well as in project design.
            Comprehensive sector reform is a complex and difficult task
            in the best of circumstances, and is perhaps impossible when
            survival issues are simultaneously on the national agenda.
            Because the reform process is complex, programs must be
            carefully and flexibly paced, particularly with a
            newly-emerging state apparatus where sector regulatory
            experience is only in its nascent stages. Furthermore,
            interventions must be continuously and intelligently
            modified during implementation, as the situation develops.
            Finally, the team should be open to the considerable
            "learning" that is involved in the reform process
            (on the part of the government, the municipalities, the
            donors and the Bank team itself), and seek to use this
            learning to inform and focus current and future project
            design. Supervision of reform is highly demanding,
            especially in a conflict-affected context. The team needs to
            be determined, sensitive to the situation as it develops,
            and flexible and proactive when necessary to keep the
            program on track. They also need to act quickly and
            decisively when derailment threatens. Also, a country-based
            supervision team is essential to ensure continuity in
            dialogue and constant monitoring of progress on the reform
            agenda. Significant implementation capacity exists even at
            the lower levels of the local government system. The project
            design included assumptions about a shifting of
            responsibility away from emergency implementation procedures
            through central agencies to the piloting of implementation
            locally through Selected Municipalities (SMs), which proved
            to be a very rewarding approach. Provided adequate technical
            support, SMs demonstrated that they are quite capable of
            undertaking medium-sized subprojects on their own. The
            smaller municipalities are quite capable of undertaking
            projects in the $0.1-0.5m range. Local institutions also
            possess considerable initiative and resiliency. This was
            amply demonstrated during the later stages of the project,
            particularly after September 2000 when movement of
            Palestinian personnel became severely restricted. During
            this period, the second and third batches of small works
            were successfully completed.

repnme.cdata!:
West Bank and Gaza - Municipal
            Infrastructure Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Municipal Infrastructure Development
            Project seeks to continue the thrusts of the Emergency
            Rehabilitation Project, but will break new ground by helping
            to initiate significant institutional reform and capacity
            building in the local government sector. Specific project
            objectives, therefore, are: 1) to help remove critical
            infrastructural bottlenecks; improve essential services and
            facilities; preserve existing infrastructural assets; and
            create productive employment; and 2) to strengthen the local
            government system, particularly to rationalize roles and
            responsibilities and build finance and managerial capacity.
            The project will consist of the following components: 1)
            infrastructure rehabilitation and improvement including: (a)
            a rehabilitation and improvement sub-program; (b) a
            maintenance sub-program; and (c) a neighborhood upgrading
            sub-program; 2) local government reform and capacity
            building comprising: (a) local government technical
            assistance and capacity building; and (b) selected
            municipality technical assistance and capacity building; and
            3) managerial support and incremental operating expenses.
